header.title: Notes on the Zohar in English

central_thesis: This paper provides a comprehensive bibliographic and critical survey of English translations of the Zohar, evaluating their scope, translation methodologies, and completeness, while offering recommendations for academic and personal study. It highlights the Zohar's foundational role in classical Kabbalah and the ongoing evolution of its scholarly and practical accessibility in English.

structure_content.chapter_title: SOURCES OF THE ZOHAR IN ENGLISH TRANSLATION
structure_content.summary: This section introduces and critically analyzes the major English translations of the Zohar, including Isaiah Tishby's Wisdom of the Zohar, the Soncino Zohar (SSL), the Kabbalah Centre's translation with Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag's Sulam commentary, Moshe Miller's Zohar: Selections, and Daniel Matt's PRITZKER EDITION. It also covers significant partial translations of specific Zoharic texts like Sifre deTzeniuta, Idrot, Midrash ha-Neelam, and Sava d'Mishpatim, noting their strengths and limitations.

Presents a structured chart categorizing the different tracts and sections within the Zohar (e.g., commentary on the Torah, Sifre deTzeniuta, Idra Rabba, Hekhalot, Raya Mehemna, Tikkunei Zohar) and cross-references them with the corresponding English translations using coded entries for easier navigation.

Offers an extensive annotated bibliography of books, book sections, and articles relevant to the Zohar, including works that contain translated passages or discuss aspects of Zoharic studies. The annotations often provide brief critical insights into each entry's content or relevance.

Provides curated reading lists for readers, distinguishing between introductory works for general acquaintance with the Zohar and a more definitive selection for committed researchers, practitioners, or librarians seeking comprehensive study. Key authors and their works are recommended, with specific mentions of their multi-volume sets.

Presents a specific translated passage from Zohar I 51b-52a, originally an omission from the Simon and Sperling translation. This section highlights the text's description of celestial illuminations, divisions of space into colors and channels, the role of thrones, and the nature of the serpent, contextualizing it by listing other English translations where this passage subsequently appeared.

key_concepts.definition: The seminal text of classical Kabbalah, comprising a collection of tracts of various sizes, primarily a running commentary on the Torah, with additional sections like Zohar Hadash and Tikkunei Zohar.

Rabbi Yehuda Ashlag's Hebrew translation of the Zohar, which includes his embedded commentary structured according to the Lurianic system of Kabbalah. It is noted for its specific interpretative framework rather than literal meaning.

Daniel Matt's ongoing critical English translation of the Zohar, based on a meticulous selection and evaluation of multiple medieval manuscripts, aiming for both literal accuracy and poetic quality, accompanied by extensive scholarly footnotes.
Divine emanations or attributes, fundamental to Lurianic Kabbalah, often used by commentators like Ashlag to interpret the Zohar's esoteric references.
Divine 'faces' or 'configurations' in Lurianic Kabbalah, representing complex arrangements of Sefirot, used in interpretative frameworks for Zoharic texts.
A particularly important mystical text within the Zohar, known for its dense and enigmatic content, focusing on cosmogony and divine structures, with several key English translations.

practical_system.description: This document itself is a meta-analysis of texts and not a practical system for magic or esotericism. However, it meticulously describes and contextualizes the Zohar, which is the foundational text for classical Kabbalah. The Zohar outlines a comprehensive mystical philosophy involving divine emanations (Sefirot), archetypal structures (Parzufim), celestial realms (Hekhalot), and esoteric interpretations of the Torah, all of which form the basis for Kabbalistic contemplation, meditation, and ritual practices aimed at spiritual ascent and understanding divine mysteries.
tools: The primary 'tool' discussed implicitly throughout this document is the Zohar itself—as a text for study, contemplation, and esoteric interpretation. Different translations are evaluated based on their utility as tools for accessing the Zohar's profound mystical content, with particular attention to explanatory notes, commentaries, and fidelity to the original Aramaic/Hebrew.
rituals: While this document does not prescribe rituals, it references studies of Kabbalistic practices, such as 'yihudim' (unifications) in Spanish Kabbalah (Verman), and the ritual aspects discussed in Idel's works, indicating that the Zohar contains the philosophical and mystical underpinnings for various contemplative and theurgic actions in Kabbalah.

relevant_quotes.text: THE ZOHAR, or Sefer ha-Zohar, is without question the major text of classical Kabbalah. It is not a single book, but rather a collection of tracts of various sizes, there being about two dozen which form fairly coherent units.

Work concerning the authorship and chronology of the zoharic strata is on-going, though most scholars agree that the main body of the Zohar was written by Rabbi Moses de Leon (1250-1305) and perhaps some others in his circle toward the end of the thirteenth century into the beginning of the fourteenth.

Matching the highest academic standards with genuine sympathy for the text—Matt describes his translation as 'literal yet poetic' (p. XX)—the PRITZKER EDITION will undoubtedly become the English Zohar of choice among scholars and informed lay readers.
Of the Sulam commentary, Isaiah Tishby (Wisdom of the Zohar, p. 105) says, "The explanations follow the Lurianic system and are of little help in clarifying the literal meaning of the text."

Gershom Scholem (Major Trends in Jewish Mysticism, p. 387, n. 34) says of SSL, “This translation is not always correct but it conveys a clear impression of what the Zohar is. It is to be regretted that too much has been omitted. The innumerable deliberate falsifications of the French translator, Jean de Pauly, are of course not to be found in this more solid and workmanlike translation."

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is exceptionally relevant for any individual or institution engaged in the study of Kabbalah, Jewish Mysticism, or Western Esotericism. It acts as an indispensable navigational tool through the complex landscape of Zohar translations, offering critical evaluations that guide readers toward the most accurate, comprehensive, and contextually rich resources. It saves considerable research time by centralizing information on diverse translations, their methodologies, and scholarly reception.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Academic researchers and scholars in Jewish Studies, Religious Studies, and Esotericism; serious students and practitioners of Kabbalah; librarians developing collections in mysticism; and anyone seeking a deep, informed entry point into Zoharic literature in English.
